evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew is evident in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 as documented in hist_t2_interim.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident remains robust against alternative interpretations or defeaters in hist_t2_interim.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including miscommunication and lack of coordination.

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew is evident in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 as documented in hist_t2_interim.

assumptions: The headset operator and wingman are considered part of the 'crew' relevant to communication/coordination
The lack of warning signals contributed to the collision
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and timely warnings were given preventing the collision
If the collision was caused by factors unrelated to communication or coordination

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows communication existed between flight crew and headset operator (H1), and between trainee and instructor (H2, H3), but the tug instructor did not receive warnings from wingman or headset operator about the impending collision (H8), and the aircraft overran the TRP causing a collision (H4). This suggests some communication/coordination breakdown among crew involved in pushback.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of communication exchanges or failures between all crew members; limited detail on coordination protocols and their adherence

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including miscommunication and lack of coordination.

assumptions: Lack of warnings and insufficient signals imply communication/coordination breakdown
The described interactions reflect key features of miscommunication and coordination failure
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing errors
If the incident was caused by factors unrelated to communication or coordination

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows communication between crew and headset operator (H1), a decision to stop pushback and handover (H2), instructor advising trainee (H3), and limitations in visual signals and lack of warnings from wingman or headset operator (H8), indicating miscommunication and coordination issues consistent with the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit direct statement of communication breakdown; inference based on described interactions and lack of warnings

node.statement: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident remains robust against alternative interpretations or defeaters in hist_t2_interim.

defeaters: Additional evidence showing effective communication or warnings that were ignored
Alternative interpretations of the visual signals or communication effectiveness

The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly describes communication methods, roles, and limitations in signaling (H1, H2, H3, H8, H9), supporting that the explanation of communication/coordination breakdown remains robust against alternative interpretations.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of alternative interpretations or contradictory communication accounts; some ambiguity in subjective assessments of signal sufficiency.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The history evidence (H1-H9) directly documents and describes the procedural deviation during pushback of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the specified timeframe, including the continuation beyond the TRP and collision with the blast barrier (H4), confirming the deviation is observable and documented.
outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; evidence is detailed and consistent
